entry.et: Middle English, from past participle of sacren to consecrate, from Anglo-French sacrer, from Latin sacrare, from sacr-, sacer sacred; akin to Latin sancire to make sacred, Hittite šaklāi- rite

def.dt: :dedicated or set apart for the service or worship of a deity a tree sacred to the gods
:devoted exclusively to one service or use (as of a person or purpose) a fund sacred to charity
:of or relating to religion :not secular or profane sacred music
:highly valued and important a sacred responsibility

entry.et: from its veneration by the ancient Egyptians
from the veneration of the cow by Hindus

def.dt: :one that is often unreasonably immune from criticism or opposition
